newsitem.title: FRANCE: France wants Aerospatiale in public sector - paper.
newsitem.headline: France wants Aerospatiale in public sector - paper.

text.p: France wants to keep state-owned plane maker Aerospatiale in the public sector after linking it with warplane manufacturer Dassault Aviation, said Defence Minister Alain Richard on Thursday.

"The government hopes to convince Dassault Aviation that this linking of forces can take place while keeping Aerospatiale in the public sector," afternoon daily Le Monde quoted Richard as saying in an interview.
The previous conservative government had planned to merge Aerospatiale and Dassault Aviation and privatise the new company.
Dassault Chairman Serge Dassault has said he would only agree to the merger if the resulting firm were privatised.
Richard said in the interview that France's overall strategy centred on a deeper European alliance in the civil aviation sector.

"Our European partners have already realised synergies between their civil and military aeronautic sectors and that is a target for France as well, but without losing sight of the final result, which is European," he said.

He repeated the government's position that they would not completely sell off defence electronics firm Thomson-CSF and said the company would have no problem finding European partners despite speculation that private companies would be reluctant to link up with a company heavily influenced by the state.
